summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to authorize a subpoena to the law firm Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP (BSF) for various documents. The court finds most requests are overbroad 'fishing expeditions' or seek materials for improper impeachment purposes, but reserves judgment on three requests pending government input.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant seeking court authorization to subpoena documents from the law firm Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP for her criminal trial and suppression motions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge issuing the order, analyzing Maxwell's subpoena request under the Nixon standard and denying most of it.

connections.description: Maxwell seeks to subpoena the law firm for documents, indicating the firm possesses materials relevant to her defense against criminal charges.

events.title: Court Denies Maxwell Subpoena Motion
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to authorize a Rule 17(c) subpoena to Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP for Requests 1-8 and 12, reserving judgment on Requests 9-11.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell sought a court order to subpoena the law firm Boies, Schiller and Flexner LLP for twelve categories of documents.
The court denied authorization for Requests 1-8 and 12, finding them overbroad 'fishing expeditions' that failed the specificity and relevance requirements of the Nixon standard.
The court specifically noted that requests for contingency fee agreements with alleged victims were for improper impeachment purposes and not discoverable pre-trial under Rule 17(c).
The court reserved judgment on Requests 9-11 and ordered the Government to provide its views on those requests within one week.
The court denied the Government's blanket request for notice of all future subpoena applications, noting ex parte applications can be justified in some circumstances.
